field_edited_text.value:
!

The Pros and Cons of Expressways



pressways have drawbacks as well as virtues. This being the case, one
possibility which should be examined would be a complete abandonment
_ of future expressway plans. What might the future hold if we did not
construct any more expressways after the Jones Falls Expressway? Or,
more specifically, what would happen if Baltimore decided not to go
ahead with the East-West Expressway?

We could, first of all, endeavor to increase the present capacity of
east-west streets by new streets or by widening existing streets. Previous
sections of this report have. indicated that all of the capacity of the
East-West Expressway would be needed to handle anticipated traffic
growth and to provide some small relief to existing streets. Since one
expressway lane is roughly the equivalent of two and one-half surface
street lanes it would require twenty new lanes of surface streets to equal
the eight lanes planned for the East-West Expressway. These 20 lanes
would have to pass from one side of the City to the other and all, or
nearly all, should cross the center of the City between the Inner Harbor
on the south and about Cold Spring Lane on the north.

It would not be possible to widen existing streets or to create new
ones without tearing down buildings. Removing all of the buildings on
one side of a street would probably permit an average of four additional
lanes to be constructed. Twenty lanes would require the razing of all
buildings on one side of each of five streets. Regardless of where located,
the East-West Expressway will require the razing of buildings on one side
of each of two streets (e.g., the south side of Franklin and the north side
of Mulberry).

Twenty additional lanes of surface streets would thus require the
removal of approximately two and one-half times as many buildings as
would the East-West Expressway. The number of families to be relocated,
the loss in taxes, and the cost of site acquisition would be in proportion.

33

Construction cost would be considerably less and, as a result, total cost
might perhaps be less. A program of creating 20 new surface street lanes
would not, however, generate any new Federal grants and the total cost
to the City would thus be very much greater than the cost to the City
for the East-West Expressway after making allowance for the very sub-
stantial Federal grants available for this purpose.

Furthermore, while 20 new surface street lanes would duplicate the
capacity of the East-West Expressway they would not provide the safety
or the savings in travel time of the East-West Expressway.

It seems evident that if the City is not willing to go ahead with an
East-West Expressway it would be even less likely to proceed with a pro-
gram which would provide the same capacity by additional surface streets.

What happens, then, if we neither build additional expressways nor
add substantially to our present surface street capacity? Here one has
to do some guessing, but the following results seem probable.

In the first place, while Mr. Barnes has accomplished remarkable
results in squeezing additional capacity out of our existing street system,
there are obviously limits to what can be achieved in this way and Mr.
Barnes would probably be the first to admit that we are approaching
these limits. From here on in, if we do not add substantially to our high-
way system, congestion will steadily increase. It would seem possible to
project present trends into the future to the point where congestion had
become so great that traffic movement was theoretically impossible. This,
however, is an unlikely result. At some point this side of complete stag-
nation certain counter forces and trends would probably come into play.

People trapped by congestion are also citizens and voters. The need
for relief would almost certainly become a major political issue which
would have to be recognized by future City administrations. Since we are
assuming that the City is unwilling to embark upon any such major
